title: 113_s1484
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013" and includes definitions. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines the term "Authority" as the Sabine River Authority of Texas and "Federal land" as specific National Forest System land in Texas. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines "non-Federal land" as private land adjacent to Sabine National Forest to be owned or acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 defines "non-Federal land" as private land adjacent to Sabine National Forest to be owned or acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas. The Act also includes terms such as "Secretary" referring to the Secretary of Agriculture, "Toledo Bend Project" as the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission project numbered 2305, and "wilderness area" as the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest designated by the Texas Wilderness Act of 1984. The term "wilderness candidate land" refers to the surface estate of land adjacent to a wilderness area, to be owned or acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. In exchange for non-Federal land, wilderness candidate land, and any cash payment, the Secretary will convey all US interests in Federal land. The conveyance is subject to existing rights and requires an appraisal within 180 days of enactment. The Secretary will appraise Federal land according to specific standards and instructions. The Secretary will appraise Federal land according to specific standards and instructions. When determining the value of the Federal land for conveyance, the Secretary must consider limitations imposed by a restrictive covenant. The exact acreage and legal description of the land to be conveyed will be determined through surveys agreed upon by the Secretary and the Authority. Costs associated with the land exchange will be covered. Costs for the land exchange will be split equally between the Authority and the Secretary. The exchange will be conducted on an equal value basis, with the option to use cash equalization payments to balance out any differences in land value. Any cash equalization payment received by the Secretary will be deposited into the fund established under Public Law 90-171 (Sisk Act) and can be used by the Secretary for land acquisition for the National Forest System. Title to non-Federal land conveyed to the Secretary will be transferred accordingly. The Secretary must appoint an acceptable individual who meets the Attorney General's title approval standards for land acquisitions by the Federal Government. The deed conveying Federal land to the Authority must reserve any subsurface mineral estate owned by the United States, including oil, gas, rock, sand, and gravel. Additionally, a restrictive covenant must be included in the deed of conveyance to the Authority. The Secretary appoints an individual meeting title approval standards for land acquisitions. The deed reserves subsurface mineral rights owned by the US. A covenant in the deed restricts commercial, residential, or industrial development on the conveyed Federal land. The Authority can operate Forest Service campgrounds after the land exchange, with completion intended within a year of the Act's enactment. Boundary adjustment for the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest is addressed in Section 4 of the Act. Boundary adjustment for the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest includes excluding land within the Toledo Bend Project and adding acquired wilderness candidate land to the wilderness area. The Secretary will designate acquired wilderness candidate land as wilderness and part of the National Wilderness Preservation System. A map and legal description of boundary changes will be filed with the relevant committees after the completion of a land exchange. The map and legal description filed for the land exchange will have the same force and effect as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. They will also be available for public inspection in Forest Service offices.
